etymologies: Old English; earliest use found in Royal Charter: Edward the Confessor to Westminster Abbey. Apparently from mis- + ken + -ing

definitions: A mistake or variation in pleading before a court.

notes.text: Found in several alleged Old English charters of Edward the Confessor preserved in late copies. These are, however, ‘Westminster writs of doubtful authenticity, or spurious’ (F. E. Harmer Anglo-Saxon Writs (1952) 82). The writs may be based on original charters, with the content altered and expanded in the 12th century. The occurrence of miskenning in these charters is probably anachronistic.
